front.title: Delegation of Signing Authority with DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM)

abstract.t: DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM) permits an agent to affix a digital signature to an email message, associating a domain name with that message with the strength provided by a cryptographic mechanism. The domain name thus attached is not, however, necessarily the same as any other domain name in the message. In particular, the domain need not match the domain found in the From field of the message, though this is the one users typically see and is thus typically considered the most important. This decoupling means DKIM cannot be used to, for example, confirm that a message signed by someone other than the author is actually content generated by that author.

What is needed is a way for an author to indicate that a signature from some third party was anticipated by the author, and thus a receiver can conclude the content is legitimately from that author. This document presents a specific application of DKIM that can achieve that goal.

section.title: Background
section.t: DomainKeys Identified Mail defines a mechanism whereby a verified domain name can be attached to a message, or portion of a message, using a cryptographic signature. It does not, however, assert that this domain name matches a domain name found anywhere else in the message.

Author Domain Signing Practices was developed as an add-on to DKIM that establishes a binding between the domain name validated by DKIM and the one visible in the From: field on a message. In essence, the ADSP test is satisfied if there exists on the message a DKIM signature whose domain name matches the one in the From: field of the message being checked. For instances where this test fails, ADSP further offers a mechanism for a domain name owner to publish via the Domain Name System a policy statement requesting that a mail receiver prevent delivery of the message.

Use of ADSP by a domain that has actual users can create problems for certain common applications. One of these is mailing lists, where strict use of ADSP can be disruptive to mailing list operation (see Section 5.2 of ). As a result of this limited utility of ADSP, it has not resulted in widespread use.
There are new efforts within this space that are encountering similar difficulties, although they have much more industry support.

The issues with mailing lists and similar re-mailing applications could be resolved by a mechanism by which the author domain ("A") can indicate that some other domain ("B") is explicitly permitted to re-mail content generated by "A", and receiver can observe signaling from both "A" and "B" that this relationship exists.

An experimental attempt to do so appeared in . The method presented there suffers from the burden on the author domain to publish those relationships a prior via the DNS. A mechanism that does not have such an external dependency is preferred.

section.title: DKIM-Delegate description
section.t: "DKIM-Delegate" is a profile of DKIM that creates an ephemeral relationship between a message author and an intermediary that can be used by a receiver to conclude that the intermediary legitimately handled a message created by the author. This makes it possible to identify such messages separately from those without such assurances, and thus the latter can be treated with more skepticism.

The specific mechanism is as follows:
The Author generates a message in the usual way.
The Author affixes a DKIM signature that includes the entire message content in the body hash. (That is, it does not use the "l=" tag.)
The Author affixes a second DKIM signature that uses an "l=" tag to sign only a portion of the message body, allowing content changes, and includes only a few key header fields in the header hash. The signature also has a short expiration time, using an "x=" tag. (See for details.)
The Author sends the message. It may or may not be handled by some intermediary agents before arriving at the Recipient.
The Recipient attempts to validate the first DKIM signature affixed by the Author. If it is valid and not expired, the requirements of this profile are satisfied (and the algorithm terminates here).
The Recipient attempts to validate the second DKIM signature affixed by the Author. If it is not valid (or not found), the requirements of this profile cannot be satisfied (and the algorithm terminates here).
The Recipient collects all header fields that were covered by the header hash of the second DKIM signature and that contain recipient addresses. These can be found in that signature's "h=" tag. The obvious examples are the To and Cc fields (if present).
The Recipient extracts the set of domain names from the collected header fields. Call this set "D".
The Recipient performs normal validation checks of all other DKIM signatures on the message that include the entire message body in their body hashes, and stores the set of domains from passing signatures in set "S".
If the intersection of "D" and "S" is not empty, the requirements of this profile are satisfied; otherwise, the requirements are not satisfied.

section.title: Discussion
section.t: The use of the first Author signature ensures that if the original message arrives intact, the Receiver is assured of its legitimacy as having been generated and sent by the Author irrespective of what intermediate agents handled it.

Mailing list software commonly makes adjustments to a message prior to sending it to subscribers, such as prepending list-identifying material to the Subject field, or appending URIs and such to the message body referring Receivers to further information about the list itself. This will almost always invalidate the first Author signature, so downstream receivers cannot be sure (via DKIM, at least) where the message originated.

The second "delegation" signature always covers the visible recipient fields of the message, but typically does not cover any of the content. Under this profile, domains that appear in those fields are permitted to alter and re-send the content so long as they also sign (and thus take responsibility for) the message thus generated.

The delegation signature typically covers only the following header fields:
From (required by DKIM)
To and Cc (contain Receiver addresses)
Message-Id (binds the signature to a specific message)
Date (binds the signature to a specific date)
Subject, though normally covered by signatures as per Section 5.4 of , can be omitted for a delegation signature if the Author anticipates legitimate alteration of it by a Mediator.
Similarly, the delegation signature typically covers the message content, but allows for legitimate Mediator modifications, by including an "l=" tag in the signature.

The expiration time on the second Author signature selected needs to be long enough to permit evaluation by recipients of the re-distribution of the message. A good choice is a small number of days or even hours.

list.t: Should we create a new DKIM signature tag that allows the Author to indicate in the delegation signature a set of authorized re-signing domains in addition to or other than the ones implicit in "To" and "Cc"?

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: Use of this profile of DKIM amounts to an ephemeral granting of the ability for the first Receivers (the Mediators named in the To and Cc fields) to generate content that the ultimate Receivers will consider valid on behalf of the Author. A compromised Mediator can thus replace the original content in its entirety while still satisfying this profile.
Section 8.2 discusses the risks of using "l=" tags when generating signatures.
